title: Create project directory structure
description:
# Task: Create Project Directory Structure

## What
Create the complete directory scaffolding for the Jekyll site as specified in PLAN.md.

## Why
Jekyll has strict conventions about directory naming. The underscore-prefixed directories have special meaning:
- `_layouts/` - Page templates (default, page, post)
- `_includes/` - Reusable HTML partials (header, footer)
- `_posts/` - Blog posts (date-prefixed markdown files)
- `_data/` - Structured data files (YAML/JSON, like navigation)
- `assets/` - Static files (CSS, images, PDFs)

## Directory Tree to Create
```
_data/
_layouts/
_includes/
_posts/
assets/
assets/css/
assets/images/
assets/files/
```

## Implementation Notes
- All directories should be empty initially (files added by subsequent tasks)
- Git doesn't track empty directories, so either:
  - Add a .gitkeep to each, OR
  - Create the directories when adding files (preferred)
- The `_posts/` directory starts empty intentionally (blog content is post-MVP)

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] All directories exist
- [ ] Directory names match Jekyll conventions exactly
- [ ] No typos in underscore prefixes

## Parent Epic
[EPIC] Project Foundation & Jekyll Setup

## Blocks
- All layout and include creation tasks
- All page creation tasks
- All asset creation tasks

title: Create _config.yml with site metadata
description:
# Task: Create _config.yml with Site Metadata

## What
Create the central Jekyll configuration file with all site settings.

## Why
_config.yml is the "control center" for the entire Jekyll site:
- Defines site title, description, author for SEO
- Specifies the theme
- Configures plugins
- Sets permalink structure
- Excludes files from build

## Configuration Specification
```yaml
title: "Miłosz Czajkowski"
description: "DevOps consultant specializing in AWS, Kubernetes, and platform engineering"
url: "https://miloszc.github.io"  # GitHub username assumed
baseurl: ""
lang: "en"
timezone: "Europe/Warsaw"

author:
  name: "Miłosz Czajkowski"
  email: "mil.czajkowski@gmail.com"
  linkedin: "milosz-czajkowski"

theme: minima

permalink: /blog/:title/

plugins:
  - jekyll-feed
  - jekyll-seo-tag
  - jekyll-sitemap

exclude:
  - Gemfile
  - Gemfile.lock
  - README.md
  - vendor
  - PLAN.md
  - CLAUDE.md
  - AGENTS.md
  - .beads/
```

## Key Decisions
1. **baseurl: ""**: Site is at root of github.io domain, not in subdirectory
2. **permalink structure**: Clean URLs like /blog/my-post/ (no dates)
3. **timezone**: Europe/Warsaw for consistent date formatting
4. **exclude list**: Keep build output clean, don't expose planning docs

## TODO Items
- [ ] Confirm actual GitHub username for url field
- [ ] Verify LinkedIn profile slug is correct

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] _config.yml exists at project root
- [ ] All author fields populated
- [ ] Theme set to minima
- [ ] All plugins listed
- [ ] Exclude list includes dev files

## Parent Epic
[EPIC] Project Foundation & Jekyll Setup

title: Create _layouts/default.html base template
description:
# Task: Create default.html Base Layout

## What
Create the base HTML template that all other layouts extend.

## Why
- Single source for HTML structure (doctype, head, body)
- Ensures consistent meta tags across all pages
- Includes SEO tags and feed link automatically
- Defines where header, content, and footer appear

## Template Structure
```html
<!DOCTYPE html>
<html lang="{{ site.lang | default: 'en' }}">
<head>
  <meta charset="utf-8">
  <meta name="viewport" content="width=device-width, initial-scale=1">
  {% seo %}
  <link rel="stylesheet" href="{{ '/assets/css/style.css' | relative_url }}">
  {% feed_meta %}
</head>
<body>
  {% include header.html %}
  <main>
    {{ content }}
  </main>
  {% include footer.html %}
</body>
</html>
```

## Key Elements Explained
1. **{% seo %}**: Jekyll SEO plugin generates title, description, OG tags
2. **{% feed_meta %}**: Adds link to RSS feed in head
3. **{{ content }}**: Where child layouts inject their content
4. **{% include %}**: Pulls in header.html and footer.html

## Implementation Notes
- No JavaScript included (MVP requirement)
- Stylesheet path uses relative_url filter for baseurl compatibility
- lang attribute from site config for accessibility

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] Valid HTML5 doctype
- [ ] Viewport meta for mobile
- [ ] SEO tag present
- [ ] Feed meta present
- [ ] Header and footer includes
- [ ] Main element wraps content

## Parent Epic
[EPIC] Layouts & Templating System

title: Create and configure Gemfile
description:
# Task: Create and Configure Gemfile

## What
Create the Ruby Gemfile that defines Jekyll and plugin dependencies.

## Why
- Gemfile is required for `bundle install` to work
- Locks specific gem versions for reproducibility
- Defines which Jekyll plugins are available
- GitHub Pages will use this for deployment

## Content Specification
```ruby
source "https://rubygems.org"

gem "jekyll", "~> 4.3"
gem "minima", "~> 2.5"

group :jekyll_plugins do
  gem "jekyll-feed"
  gem "jekyll-seo-tag"
  gem "jekyll-sitemap"
end
```

## Plugin Justification
1. **jekyll-feed**: Generates RSS/Atom feed at /feed.xml
   - Enables blog subscription
   - Good for SEO and discoverability
   
2. **jekyll-seo-tag**: Auto-generates meta tags
   - Title, description, Open Graph tags
   - Critical for search engine visibility
   - Reduces manual HTML work
   
3. **jekyll-sitemap**: Generates sitemap.xml
   - Helps search engines index all pages
   - Required for proper SEO

## Implementation Notes
- After creating, run `bundle install`
- This will create Gemfile.lock (should be committed)
- If bundle fails, check Ruby version (needs 2.5+)

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] Gemfile created at project root
- [ ] `bundle install` completes without errors
- [ ] Gemfile.lock generated
- [ ] All three plugins listed

## Parent Epic
[EPIC] Project Foundation & Jekyll Setup

title: Create robots.txt for SEO
description:
# Task: Create robots.txt

## What
Create robots.txt file to guide search engine crawlers.

## Why
- Tells search engines they can crawl the entire site
- Points to sitemap.xml location
- Standard SEO practice
- Small file, big impact on discoverability

## Content Specification
```
User-agent: *
Allow: /
Sitemap: https://miloszc.github.io/sitemap.xml
```

## Implementation Notes
- File goes at project root (not in assets)
- Jekyll will copy it to site root during build
- Update the sitemap URL with actual GitHub username

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] robots.txt exists at project root
- [ ] Allows all user agents
- [ ] Sitemap URL is correct

## Parent Epic
[EPIC] Project Foundation & Jekyll Setup

title: Create _layouts/page.html for static pages
description:
# Task: Create page.html Layout ## What Create the layout for static content pages (Services, About, Contact, Blog). ## Why - Extends default layout with page-specific structure - Displays page title as H1 consistently - Wraps content in semantic article element - Separates page structure from content ## Template Structure ```html --- layout: default ---

{{ page.title }}

{{ content }}
``` ## How It Works 1. Front matter `layout: default` means this extends default.html 2. `{{ page.title }}` pulls from each page's front matter 3. `{{ content }}` is the page's markdown rendered to HTML 4. CSS classes allow styling hooks ## Usage Pages use this layout in their front matter: ```yaml --- layout: page title: "Services" permalink: /services/ --- ``` ## Acceptance Criteria - [ ] Extends default layout - [ ] Displays page.title as H1 - [ ] Content wrapped in article - [ ] Works with all static pages ## Parent Epic [EPIC] Layouts & Templating System

title: Verify local Jekyll development server
description:
# Task: Verify Local Development Server

## What
Run the Jekyll development server and confirm the site builds and serves correctly.

## Why
- Validates all configuration is correct
- Catches errors early before page development
- Establishes working development workflow
- Gate before proceeding to layout/page work

## Commands to Run
```bash
# Install dependencies
bundle install

# Start development server with live reload
bundle exec jekyll serve --livereload

# Expected output:
# Server address: http://127.0.0.1:4000/
# Server running... press ctrl-c to stop.
```

## What to Verify
1. No build errors or warnings
2. Site accessible at http://localhost:4000
3. Live reload works (changes trigger rebuild)
4. Minima theme styling appears

## Troubleshooting
- **Missing gem errors**: Run `bundle install`
- **Address in use**: Another process on port 4000, use `--port 4001`
- **Ruby version errors**: Need Ruby 2.5+
- **Permission errors**: May need to use `bundle exec`

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] `bundle install` succeeds
- [ ] `bundle exec jekyll serve` starts without errors
- [ ] Site loads in browser at localhost:4000
- [ ] No build warnings in console

## Parent Epic
[EPIC] Project Foundation & Jekyll Setup

## Depends On
All other Phase 1 tasks must be complete first.

title: [EPIC] Project Foundation & Jekyll Setup
description:
# Epic: Project Foundation & Jekyll Setup

## Overview
This epic covers the foundational setup required before any other work can begin. It establishes the directory structure, dependency management, and core configuration that all other components depend on.

## Strategic Importance
- **Blocking Status**: This is P0 (critical) because EVERY other task depends on the project being properly initialized
- **Risk Mitigation**: Getting config right first prevents cascading issues later
- **Developer Experience**: Proper setup enables local development workflow from day one

## Background & Context
We're building a Jekyll static site for GitHub Pages. Jekyll requires specific directory conventions:
- `_` prefixed directories have special meaning (_layouts, _includes, _posts, _data)
- Gemfile defines Ruby dependencies including Jekyll version and plugins
- _config.yml is the central nervous system of the site

## Success Criteria
- [ ] All required directories exist with correct naming
- [ ] Gemfile installs without errors
- [ ] `bundle exec jekyll serve` runs successfully
- [ ] Site loads at localhost:4000
- [ ] No Jekyll warnings about missing files

## Technical Decisions
1. **Jekyll 4.3**: Latest stable, GitHub Pages compatible
2. **Minima 2.5**: Default theme, minimal customization needed
3. **Three plugins**: feed, seo-tag, sitemap (all GitHub Pages whitelisted)

## Dependencies
None - this is the root of the dependency tree.

## Subtasks (see linked issues)
1. Create directory structure
2. Create and configure Gemfile
3. Create _config.yml with site metadata
4. Create navigation data file
5. Create robots.txt
6. Verify local development server works

title: Create _includes/footer.html
description:
# Task: Create footer.html Include ## What Create the site footer component with copyright, credits, and social links. ## Why - Consistent footer across all pages - Professional site credits - Social/contact links accessible from every page - Dynamic copyright year ## Template Structure ```html

© {{ site.time | date: '%Y' }} {{ site.author.name }}

Built with Jekyll • Hosted on GitHub Pages

LinkedIn • Email

``` ## Key Elements 1. **Dynamic year**: `site.time | date: '%Y'` always shows current year 2. **Author from config**: Single source of truth for name 3. **Tech credits**: Professional acknowledgment of tools 4. **LinkedIn/Email**: Uses values from _config.yml ## Design Notes - Three paragraphs for logical grouping - Links open in same tab (standard for navigation) - Minimal design matching Minima theme ## Acceptance Criteria - [ ] Copyright shows current year - [ ] Author name from config - [ ] Jekyll and GitHub Pages credited - [ ] LinkedIn link works - [ ] Email link is mailto ## Parent Epic [EPIC] Layouts & Templating System

title: Create _includes/header.html with navigation
description:
# Task: Create header.html Include ## What Create the site header component with logo/title and navigation menu. ## Why - Consistent header across all pages - Single place to modify navigation structure - Clean separation between structure and data - Links to navigation.yml for dynamic menu ## Template Structure ```html
{{ site.title | escape }}
{% for item in site.data.navigation.main %} {{ item.title }} {% endfor %}
``` ## Key Design Decisions 1. **No hamburger menu**: Minima CSS handles mobile stacking 2. **Site title as home link**: Common pattern, saves nav space 3. **Loop over data file**: Easy to update menu without HTML changes 4. **relative_url filter**: Handles baseurl correctly ## How Navigation Works - Reads from `_data/navigation.yml` - Loops over `main` array - Each item has `title` and `url` properties - Order in YAML = order in menu ## CSS Notes Minima theme provides: - `.site-header` styling - `.site-nav` responsive behavior - Link hover states ## Acceptance Criteria - [ ] Site title links to home - [ ] Navigation loops from data file - [ ] All 4 nav items appear - [ ] Mobile responsive (via Minima CSS) ## Parent Epic [EPIC] Layouts & Templating System ## Depends On - _data/navigation.yml must exist for loop to work

title: Create _data/navigation.yml
description: # Task: Create Navigation Data File ## What Create the navigation.yml data file that defines the site's main menu structure. ## Why - Separates navigation structure from layout code - Single source of truth for menu items - Easy to modify without touching HTML - Jekyll's _data directory convention for structured data ## Content Specification ```yaml main: - title: "Services" url: /services/ - title: "About" url: /about/ - title: "Blog" url: /blog/ - title: "Contact" url: /contact/ ``` ## Design Decisions 1. **No Home link**: Site title in header serves as home link 2. **Order**: Services first (business priority), Contact last (typical pattern) 3. **Trailing slashes**: Consistent with Jekyll permalink defaults 4. **Nested under 'main'**: Allows for future footer nav or secondary nav ## How It's Used The header.html include will loop over this: ```liquid {% for item in site.data.navigation.main %} {{ item.title }} {% endfor %} ``` ## Acceptance Criteria - [ ] File exists at _data/navigation.yml - [ ] YAML syntax is valid - [ ] All 4 pages represented - [ ] URLs match page permalinks ## Parent Epic [EPIC] Project Foundation & Jekyll Setup

title: [EPIC] Layouts & Templating System
description:
# Epic: Layouts & Templating System

## Overview
This epic covers the creation of Jekyll layouts and includes that form the structural foundation for all content pages. Layouts define how pages render; includes provide reusable components.

## Strategic Importance
- **Foundation for Content**: All 5 content pages depend on these layouts
- **Consistency**: Ensures uniform look and feel across the site
- **Maintainability**: Changes to header/footer propagate everywhere
- **SEO**: Default layout includes meta tags and feed links

## Architecture
```
_layouts/
├── default.html  ← Base template, all others extend this
├── page.html     ← For static pages (Services, About, Contact)
└── post.html     ← For blog posts (date + author display)

_includes/
├── header.html   ← Site title + navigation
└── footer.html   ← Copyright + credits + social links
```

## Template Inheritance
```
default.html
    ├── page.html    (extends default)
    └── post.html    (extends default)
```

## Key Technical Decisions
1. **Minimal JavaScript**: No JS in MVP (pure HTML/CSS)
2. **No hamburger menu**: CSS handles mobile stacking
3. **SEO tags in default.html**: Ensures all pages get proper meta
4. **Single-level layout hierarchy**: Keeps it simple

## Dependencies
- Depends on: Epic 1 (Foundation) must be complete
- Blocks: Epic 3 (Content Pages) cannot proceed without layouts

## Success Criteria
- [ ] All layouts render without errors
- [ ] Page layout shows title as H1
- [ ] Post layout shows date and author
- [ ] Header navigation works
- [ ] Footer shows copyright year dynamically

## Subtasks (see linked issues)
1. Create default.html base layout
2. Create page.html layout
3. Create post.html layout
4. Create header.html include
5. Create footer.html include

title: Create _layouts/post.html for blog posts
description:
# Task: Create post.html Layout ## What Create the layout for blog posts with date, author, and back-link. ## Why - Blog posts need metadata display (date, author) - Different from static pages in information hierarchy - Provides navigation back to blog listing - Ready for when blog content is added post-MVP ## Template Structure ```html --- layout: default ---

{{ page.title }}

{{ page.date | date: "%B %-d, %Y" }} {% if page.author %} • {{ page.author }}{% endif %}

{{ content }}
← Back to blog
``` ## Key Elements 1. **datetime attribute**: Machine-readable date for SEO 2. **Formatted date**: Human-readable (e.g., "January 15, 2025") 3. **Optional author**: Uses site.author if page.author not set 4. **Back link**: Easy navigation to blog listing ## Acceptance Criteria - [ ] Extends default layout - [ ] Shows post date in readable format - [ ] Shows author if present - [ ] Has back to blog link - [ ] Uses semantic time element ## Parent Epic [EPIC] Layouts & Templating System ## Note Lower priority since blog content is post-MVP, but layout must exist for blog.md page.
